Row.Text: Good day. You stand before Sheiyksh, the Chief of the Tlingit.
How did you come to be here? I am Sheiyksh, who leads the Ravens and Eagles, the People of the Tides.
Fine, take my hat. That's all you wanted, right?
Good to see you, friend.
Excellent. You're just it time. I was on the verge of getting bored.
Oh, good! Someone to talk to. I was in the mood for a challenge of wits... assuming, of course, you're up to the challenge.
Oh, hey. Want to go fishing?
I'm good. You?
It is good to see you.
Oh, hey! I was just trying to figure out if your hat would fit on my head. It's so convenient that you've come to give it to me.
Welcome back to the lands of the Tlingit. You would do well to come live here. As a slave, of course.
You know, now that you're here I don't even want breakfast anymore. You should be ashamed of being such an eyesore.
If I didn't know better, I'd say you wanted to try taking my hat. On my own land. Pity you can't possibly win such a fight.

Nice land around here, right? I see you really want to take a lot of it. Which is alright. I think. Except if it's land that us Tlingit want. Or coasts. You really shouldn't take the coastlands. People who take the coasts from the Tlingit often end up hurt. Or slaves.
We don't have enough of this. Can you help?
You know, I was just thinking about how nice this would be in my hut. What do you think? Does it go with my hat?
You know what would be great? If we could go for walks and go hunting and fishing and pick berries without worrying that we might have crossed an invisible colored line and caused a war. Sound good?
What, you think you can take my hat? Mark my words, you will regret this mistake every day as you carry my water.
Finally, you will carry my water and I will take your name and take your hat and it will be glorious and go down as a favorite story for firelight and a song for women to sing!
Oh, you think to make us your slaves, to slay our warriors and force us to carry your water? Today, you will beg to carry my water!
